title: Stirling numbers of the second kind
summary: In mathematics, particularly in combinatorics, a Stirling number of the second kind (or Stirling partition number) is the number of ways to partition a set of n objects into k non-empty subsets and is denoted by S ( n , k ) {\displaystyle S(n,k)} or { n k } {\displaystyle \textstyle \left\{{n \atop k}\right\}} .[1] Stirling numbers of the second kind occur in the field of  mathematics called combinatorics and the study of partitions.
